body:
### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.7.0

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

Yes.

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

xterm 372-1

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

Arch default repository

### How to reproduce the issue

I have a couple of boxes that shares some folders via Samba. These shares are mounted using cifs.

Whenever I edit a text file on one of these shares, I keep getting:

`WARNING: The file has been changed since reading it!!!`

And I have to constantly press `Y`, which is extremely annoying. The file has not been changed, nothing touches the file except Neovim.

I am using this both on the ZFS filesystem and EXT4, which are both shared by Samba.

Since nothing but Neovim is touching the file, it has NOT changed in any way, and it should not continuously display this message.

### Expected behavior

Described above.

### Actual behavior

Described above.

comment_data.body: Does this bug exist on earlier versions?
Yes, I have lived with this problem for a couple of years - in silent pain :)

It would be really useful if Neovim had this as an option to disable this warning, because besides from problems with network mounted shares, other situations arise in which people complain about this feature bothering them (just search for it).

This is an example of a valid annoyance with Git: http://nelsonware.com/blog/2018/07/26/eliminate-warning-the-file-has-been-changed-since-reading-it-warning-in-neovim.html

In my specific use case, I just want this behavior to stop. I write a LOT and save a lot during typing, each time I have to press "Y", and then another key to continue, it is extremely frustrating.

Also, I suspect this problem actually might exist simply because of a slight delay in time between the machine sharing the folder and the machine on which Neovim is running. Even the smallest deviation can result in this problem because from when Neovim actually wrote to the file and then when this is actually registered on the network share might differ.

I have both machine running with NTP, but even then, there is always a minor deviation, and I highly suspect this is the problem.

Hence, the user needs to be able to disable this feature when it doesn't work correctly.

Does this help?
```vim
autocmd FileChangedShell * let v:fcs_choice = 'reload'
```
You can also change the `*` to a file path pattern.

I will test that.

A "workaround" is to add `actimeo=0` to the fstab option when mouting, but that causes a MAJOR performance penalty for CIFS, in that the timestamps are not cached. Searching through a library of text files gives the performance change:

```
With actimeo=0

real    0m3.443s

Without:

real    0m0.914s
```

So I really don't want to do that.

> ```viml
> autocmd FileChangedShell * let v:fcs_choice = 'reload'
> ```

No, that doesn't solve the issue.
The problem of course also exist on Vim.

I suspect that the issue has something to do with the fact that the write operation is updating the timestamp before Samba is finished with the file, or because that the time is delayed due to minor network latency or a slight mismatch in the time between the machines. As such, it's pretty difficult to fix outside of Vim/Neovim, and the feature needs to be able to be disabled for work with network shares IMHO.
Related Vim issue: <https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/5936>

The rejection to fix this upstream is not a valid reason. It would be really nice if Neovim would have this changed to be an option. I am on Arch Linux, the easiest solution for me is to patch this out of Neovim completely, but it's really annoying because I have to keep up with upstream Neovim for updates.

I think it really important to understand that the reason why Vim has this functionality to begin with, is because the author believes that Vim should protect the user from doing "stupid" things.

First of all, I don't want my text editor to protect me from anything. I use `rm` daily and if I want protection, I'll set it up myself.

Secondly, this so-called protection clearly doesn't work when dealing with network shares, hence it should at MOST be an option that can be disabled.

Every time I save a file, which is about a gazillion times a day, because I do a LOT of writing, I have to press "y", and then another key to continue, after I already told Neovim to save the file. It happens so many times a day that it's driving me crazy, and there is nothing I can do on the network side because the difference in the timestamp is tiny.

Related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7270

If the only change is the mtime then I agree we should relax this (either remove it or make it optional).

1. when the file is first loaded, store a hash of the file contents
2. when the user writes the file, if the mtime changes, read the file contents and compare it to the original hash
3. if the hashes match, don't show a warning.

@gpanders thank you for the suggestion. I did a mapping with `:checktime`, but the issue still persists.

According to upstream Vim, the feature is there to protect the user. But really, IMHO the job of the text editor is NOT to protect users. At least not in this intrusive and obstructive way. As a help for those who want it, fine, but being able to either opt-in or opt-out is absolutely a MUST have feature. If Vim/Neovim want's to protect the user, at least let the user decide whether he wants any protecting in the first place.

> IMHO the job of the text editor is NOT to protect users

That is the wrong theme, so no need to keep repeating it. Vim/Nvim definitely are intended to make editing pleasant and unanxious (hence 'undofile', 'swapfile', etc.), not a footgun.

Can you confirm that you are getting this warning because an external factor changed _only_ the mtime (not the file contents)?

This really seems like a bug in Samba/whatever. If I understand correctly, your mount system is touching your file / updating its mtime, but not changing its contents. Why is it updating the file's "modified time" if it isn't modifying the file?

If am understanding correctly, the issue is that Vim and Neovim check the mtime to see if the file has changed since it was last read, and warn you if you are writing edits that were applied to a version of the file prior to the one currently on disk, as determined by mtime. What do you think the editor should do instead? The editor could hash the entire file on every read/write and use hash equality instead of mtime as the modified check, but this is a lot of overhead for large files, and I like my text editor to be able to work with GB-sized files at least in principle.

We could check for modified status by:
- compare file sizes
- if file sizes equal
  - if below some size (10 MB or something), compare hashes
  - else use mtime

Another option is adding an Ex command, or changing `:w! %` to not show this warning.

---

Edit: https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/5936#issuecomment-1118871584

It's not a bug in Samba or NFS. The problem is that it's NOT the job of the text editor to mess around with this. The problem occurs when Vim/Neovim itself are saving the file. **Only** Vim is touching the files, nothing else is. But modified time is not that simple when you're working with files over a network.

> That is the wrong theme, so no need to keep repeating it. Vim/Nvim definitely are intended to make editing pleasant and unanxious (hence 'undofile', 'swapfile', etc.), not a footgun.

But that's the point exactly. Having undo and swap are all options, I can enable/disable those. This feature, I cannot.

> Can you confirm that you are getting this warning because an external factor changed _only_ the mtime (not the file contents)?

It's **only** Neovim that is touching the files. Nothing else, but you have to take into account how network sharing works, both on Samba and NFS, which is different.

This feature is not working as is should with network sharing and it's so simple, just make this feature an option. Let the user decide. Problem solved for all. There is no need to go around and around with this starting to debug Samba shares.

It sounds like this is either a bug in your FS driver/setup (an mtime gets set that is earlier than the present time from your machine's perspective when writing a file to a shared FS from your machine), or a bug in Neovim (messing up the mtime somehow). In the latter case we should fix the bug. In the former case Samba/whatever should fix the bug.

Adding a few lines of code to make something like this optional isn't a lot of work, but maintaining it over time, documentation, dealing with branches in the code, etc., adds complexity and work over time.

By the way, do you agree that if an mtime gets set that is earlier than the present time from your machine's perspective when writing a file to a shared FS from your machine, that counts as a bug in your driver/setup?

(Edit: to be clear, I'm not a core maintainer or anything, this is just IMHO.)

I am sorry, but I don't want to spend any more time with this. I strongly believe that this feature is so stupid that I simply won't run with it. I have cloned the repo, removed the function and build a local package. No more warning. Done.
This is something we should improve. Tracked in #7270
I didn't see `'writeany'` mentioned in this thread, but another possibility is to make that setting also ignore the "this file has been changed" dialog.

Even if closed, the issue seems not resolved and still valid? At least for the currently quite old debian stable distribution this is the case. 

The reason is: if someone writes a file client side on samba/cifs, the file gets a modification timestamp on the client, which caches this metadata. Then the file gets transferred to the server and gets a server side timestamp. This server side timestamp differs from the client side timestamp. It doesn't matter how exactly synchonized both times are, there is a difference and this is visible afterwards. 

This server side timestamp is the valid timestamp and gets synchronized to the client at least after invalidity of its caches. 

The cifs parameter actimeo is responsible for the validity time of the timestamp. That's the reason why actimeo=0 helps. But with actimeo=0 the cache gets disabled. This has other disadvantages. Big disadvantages. So this is not a solution. 

While it seems not feasible for me to change the behavior of samba/cifs to the one NFS uses (which does not have this problem AFAIK), it should be quite easy to change vim here. There should be some event/trigger if the file changes. This should then trigger an autoread. 

After writing the file, the user typically does not instantaneously edit the file again. It needs some seconds to do so. But the samba/cifs system changes the timestamp typically within a second. 

So some trigger, which reloads the file on changed modification date, or even after a fixed one second interval, will almost always reload the still unmodified file, but with an updated modification timestamp. 

I'm not a vim expert. Does some have a clue if there is such kind of a trigger? 

A trigger watching for changed attributes would be the best option. But even a fixed ~1 second interval after writing a file and then autoreloading should be fine.

> At least for the currently quite old debian stable distribution this is the case.

You are not going to even mention which version of Nvim you are using?

Did you check the linked PRs, such as https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18665 ? Why isn't `:write!` (with "!") an acceptable approach?

Thank you for your answer. I hadn't expected some answer on an already closed issue. It was just meant as a hint.

The current "solution", the one you mentioned, skips any warnings even if the file has indeed changed. Doesn't it? I won't call this a solution. It's a workaround - and probably a really bad one, I think. 

My approach would be a simple configuration change and would be a quite better workaround: suppresses the warning if the file content wasn't changed but give a warning if it has changed. Yet I do not know if it works at all, as I do not know if scripting within the vim/nvim configuration is possible in this way. 

And, as you said, it's not needed for those who think using `:write!` (with an exclamation mark) is acceptable for those cases where the user typically uses no exclamation mark. 

And yes, my first sentence was a question, if this is still the case with current neovim versions, as I do not use neovim at all. As this closed issue does not refer any fixes and I didn't check newer versions (referring to "debian stable" should be clear a statement). However, in the meantime, I checked a newer version (standard Arch Linux package, version 0.11.3-1) and the issue itself is still present.

PS, thinking of something like: 

```
set autoread
autocmd FileWritePost * call timer_start(1000, { tid -> execute('checktime')})
autocmd BufWritePost * call timer_start(1000, { tid -> execute('checktime')})

```
It works most of the time. But it is not 100% reliable. Re-editing within the 1 second timer prevents autoread and if the server needs more than one second this also does not work. (For working remote via the internet, for example mounting cifs over some VPN tunnel, more than one second is needed.)

labels.name: needs:vim-patch
